results.title: Dispensing a cure
results.brief_description: One of 6 works created in 2003 by community artist Malcolm McKinnon specifically for the MAP project. Each of the works focuses on a different aspect of memory and identity in the Wimmera/Mallee region. Ian Darling and Doug McColl have each practised pharmacy for over forty years in the Warracknabeal district. In this film they recall the era when most drugs were hand-made on the premises, generally from raw materials. Ian also tells of the mysterious medicine jar labelled ‘ADT’ and of an old-fashioned coin-operated machine for a self administered electric shock.

results.title: Birth of a film festival
results.brief_description: Not many people know that the Melbourne International Film Festival was born at Olinda on the Australia Day weekend in January 1952, when a group of die-hard film buffs found that the only way they could see the European and Asian films they craved was to organise their own film festival. This documentary, filmed at the 50th Melbourne International Film Festival opening night, provides a fascinating glimpse of a significant event in Australian film culture through interviews, archival footage and stills.

results.title: Fast film
results.brief_description: This ingenious cut out animation is the chase film to end all chase films. Borrowing images and characters from various Hollywood classics, ‘Fast film’ then distorts and twists our understanding of where these icons of Hollywood folklore belong. Ultimately mutating into a new narrative where the suave Cary Grant and Frankenstein’s monster happily co-exist side by side.

results.title: Bolgene
results.brief_description: Two young men who have been boyhood friends for years are taking their regular holiday together on a Scandanavian island. However, with approaching adulthood, the sexual tensions in their relationships begin to emerge. This is a serious and beautifully crafted story about adolescence and innocence, and the inevitability of change. By concentrating on the physicality and intimacy of the two male bodies in space, Mosvold creates a haunting, resonating work.

results.title: Frank's cowshed
results.brief_description: When Cohuna Higher Elementary School wanted to raise money for a film projector, local resident Tom Olsson decided to help by filming life in the township and surrounding countryside, and then showing the footage in the local Town Hall. His footage has been lovingly compiled by the Cohuna Historical Society and the resulting film gives us a special glimpse into rural life in 1950s Victoria. The school received their projector, and Olsson’s films were shown annually as a Christmas treat for many years afterward. This segment documents, at the time, the world famous invention of a step up cowshed by local resident Frank Mathers.

results.title: Ararat
results.brief_description: When Noel Matthews watched this old film to see if it could go into the MAP project he realised that it was of enormous personal significance to him. This footage of Ararat township circa 1930 is combined with a voiceover by Noel explaining why watching this film had such a powerful effect. One of earliest submissions to the MAP project.

results.title: 70 years at Brunswick Baths
results.brief_description: Brunswick - Harry Ivory, a fitness fanatic, a boxer, boxing trainer and local legend has been attending the Brunswick Baths since the day it opened in 1928. Part of a longer documentary about Harry’s life, this 4 minute film was made especially for the MAP project and focuses on the importance to him of the Brunswick Baths and the Baths community. Harry loves the place and often says it is the Baths that keep him going.

results.title: Froggie's gone
results.brief_description: This warmly comic documentary is about Beryl from Brunswick whose prized garden frog is stolen from her verandah. Very soon the police and the neighbours are on the trail of the thieves, everyone wanting to do their bit to ensure that Froggie comes back home where he belongs. This acclaimed short film was made by Beryl’s niece as a celebration of community, and is an example of how remembering an episode from your life can make a wonderful piece of film.

results.title: Expectant spaces
results.brief_description: A commissioned Public Imaging project by Melbourne cinematographer, Ben Speth. His extraordinary, meditative work manifests as a mysterious visual documentation of volume, light and time in deserted urban spaces. A sense of expectancy emerges through his still, ghostly and enigmatic images of spaces of waiting or anticipation - hospital emergency rooms, bus shelters, classrooms, dental waiting rooms, car parks.

results.title: Blue
results.creator_credit: Curtis Wehrfritz, Bruce McDonald and Don McKellar
results.brief_description: Canadian horror director David Cronenberg puts in an impressive performance as a bored carpert factory executive whose daily routine involves minor flirtations with his secretary and cronic masturbation in the privacy of his office. This explicit and ultimately melancholy tale of pornography and loneliness is intercut with a 1960s era stag loop called ‘The bellboy and the bored housewife’ and features the film’s star reminiscing about her experiences in the sex trade.
